The Dispossessed—which celebrates its 50th anniversary this year—is included on The Atlantic's new list of the Great American Novels. Meng Jin writes, "More than a novel, this is an ontological work of extraordinary imagination and compassion." 

www.theatlantic.com/books/archiv...

These illustrations by Mária Kekeláková are a selection of the images that will appear in an upcoming Czech edition of The Word for World is Forest. You can see more of her art here: 

mariakekelakova.github.io
Also available on YouTube @@4294099
Catching up on edits from a 1997 interview about The Left Hand of Darkness, here Ursula talks about the sound and rhythm of writing.
Correction: That should be @@284339!

We're thrilled to announce the selection panel for the 2024 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction:

Margaret Atwood
Omar El Akkad
Megan Giddings @@34876
Ken Liu @@1253281
Carmen Maria Machado

During April, you're welcome to nominate a book! See www.ursulakleguin.com/prize24

The original Leo and Diane Dillon cover art for The Left Hand of Darkness was recently hand-delivered by bookseller Mark Funke (left) to the Eaton Collection at UC Riverside, where it will soon be on display. 

Many thanks to Dr. Phoenix Alexander (right) for the photo!

Happy publication week to Five Novels! This new Library of America volume includes The Lathe of Heaven, The Eye of the Heron, The Beginning Place, Searoad, and Lavinia.

Many thanks to Library of America for the photo.

www.loa.org/books/five-n...

Since we can't post videos here (yet?), a cross-platform note: Over at Instagram (and on Facebook) we've been sharing clips from a 1997 interview Dr. Karen Mann did with Ursula, in which she discusses The Left Hand of Darkness and other topics. Here's the latest:

For a limited time, the black-and-white print of Ursula's map of Earthsea is available at a lower price. All proceeds from the sale of these maps will be donated to the Freedom to Read Foundation! pmpress.org/index.php?l=...

Ursula's essay collection The Wave in the Mind turned 20 on Saturday, February 17th. The book's title comes from a letter Virginia Woolf wrote to Vita Sackville-West; Woolf wrote, "A sight, an emotion, creates this wave in the mind..." 

(The full sentence is in the alt text.)

In April, Editions de l'éclat will publish Ursula's Imaginer lire écrire (The Wave in the Mind). This edition has as its preface a piece by Theo Downes-Le Guin that was published in The Guardian a year after Ursula's passing.

Cover photograph by Patricia Farazzi.
Happy 20th anniversary to The Wave in the Mind, first published on February 17th, 2004!
"The Question I Get Asked Most Often" appears in The Wave in the Mind, which turns 20 tomorrow! The essay collection was published by Shambhala on February 17, 2004. www.shambhala.com/the-wave-in-...
A nice follow-up to yesterday's Valentine's photo:

💘 Happy valentine's day!

Ursula and Charles in Paris, 1953/54.
At this moment, there are exactly three color maps of Earthsea remaining...
UCR’s acquisition of ‘The Left Hand of Darkness’ cover art has been covered by NPR! Check out the article to find out more about the process, and why the piece is so important for SF history.
At Powell's, a "starter pack" list of suggestions as to where to start reading Ursula's work:

From the Dramatic Works section of Always Coming Home; art by Margaret Chodos-Irvine.

www.harpercollins.com/products/alw...
"A forest ecology is a delicate one. If the forest perishes, its fauna may go with it. The Athshean word for world is also the word for forest."
In November, filmmaker Arwen Curry was interviewed at the Library of America blog: www.loa.org/news-and-vie...
The original cover art for The Left Hand of Darkness, painted by Leo and Diane Dillon, will be on display at UC Riverside's Eaton Collection of Science Fiction & Fantasy starting this summer.
Here are the eye-catching covers for new editions of the Annals of the Western Shore trilogy, to be published in China by Dook Media Group Limited.

There are still limited edition prints of Ursula's hand-drawn map of Earthsea! Here's a close-up look at Gont, the island where Ged's story begins.

Color and black-and-white versions are available. pmpress.org/index.php?l=...
This is today - in just a few hours!
(This quote is from Ursula's introduction to the 1977 edition of Rocannon's World. The introduction appears in full in The Language of the Night.)

"When I set out to write my first science fiction novel, in the century's mid-sixties and my own mid-thirties, I had written several novels, but I had never before invented a planet. It is a mysterious business, creating worlds out of words."

"With high invention and deep intelligence, Always Coming Home presents ... Ursula K. Le Guin's most consistently lyric and luminous book in a career adorned with some of the most precise and passionate prose in the service of a major imaginative vision." — The New York Times

On January 23rd, join Theo Downes-Le Guin, biographer Julie Phillips, and writer Nicola Griffith for an evening of appreciation and exploration of Ursula's work. The conversation will be chaired by writer & curator Sarah Shin. Register: thebritishlibraryculturalevents.seetickets.com/event/the-re...

"If you'd like a story about how I won my basketball letter and achieved fame, love, and fortune, don't read this. I don't know what I achieved in the six months I'm going to tell about. I achieved something, all right, but I think it may take me the rest of my life to find out what."

Starting next week, Karen Joy Fowler is teaching a class on Ursula's work and craft for the Writers' Annex. As Karen's intro explains: “We will talk about her politics, her utopias, her dystopias, about the subversive potential of fantasy, about her intentions, about her prose, and her craft.”

Soon, The Language of the Night will be available once again! Ursula's 1979 collection of essays will be reissued by Scribner on May 14th, with a new introduction from author Ken Liu.

More details: www.simonandschuster.com/books/The-La...

Although the first book has been available for years in translation by Mona Elnamoury, it has been Mona's dream for years to update her original translation, and to include the other books. She'll be doing this in collaboration with SFF writer/translator Ahmed Al-mahdi.
Excited to share that the first five books of Earthsea will be translated and published in Arabic (the sixth will follow as funding for the translation becomes available next year).

Today is Charles and Ursula’s wedding anniversary (December 22, 1953).

Photo by Dale Wittner.
A note: This edition is still making its way into the world, but can be obtained directly from Stelliform Press: www.stelliform.press/index.php/pr...
The new edition of Arboreality by @@554579 - winner of the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction - features the prize seal, and has the title in shiny gold foil!
"The Fisherwoman's Daughter" appears in Dancing at the Edge of the World (Grove Press, 1989).

“The imagination is an essential tool of the mind, a fundamental way of thinking, an indispensable means of becoming and remaining human.”
—“The Operating Instructions” (2002)
Look at the pretty books I got in the mail today! They're new editions of some of my favorite @@1866 stories, from Winter Texts in Port Townsend, WA.

A selection of Ursula’s VERY SASSY responses to Rona Jaffe’s PERFECTLY REASONABLE questions about her life from a Radcliffe alumna questionnaire ca. 1980 (never submitted, sadly). Thanks to Julie Phillips for this gem.

Me at the fantasy show at the British Library, peering at @@1866's ms of A Wizard of Earthsea. She said it was the first of her books that "came out whole," that appeared in her mind and just needed to be written down. Her original title for it was "A Shadow on the Sea."
It just went live: pmpress.org/index.php?l=...
Prints are available now! pmpress.org/index.php?l=...

Here's a close-up peek at limited edition prints of Ursula's map of Earthsea, which will go on sale via PM Press tomorrow morning (12/1) at 9 am PST! Proceeds from the sale of these maps will go to the Freedom to Read Foundation and to Pacific Northwest College of Art.

Sunday Nov 26, 18:45 GMT, BBC Radio 3 airs "Afterwords - Ursula Le Guin", with writers Katherine Rundell and So Mayer, anthropologist and drag artist Cheddar Gorgeous, collaborator, friend and musician Todd Barton.

"Always Coming Home has the potential to become the Lord of the Rings of an ecologically alarmed generation.“ 
—German critic Denis Scheck

The German edition is translated by Matthias Fersterer, Karen Nölle, and Helmut W. Pesch, and published by Carcosa Verlag. 

www.daserste.de/information/...

All the Catwings books are once again in flight! (Or in print, to be more accurate.)

Pard approves.

www.simonandschuster.com/series/Catwi...
Autumnal mélange from Ursula's house.

BTW beside Bernie Taupin rightfully trashing Jann Wenner last night (and not even having to mention his name! perfect shade), major kudos for him saluting among his many influences Ray Bradbury, Mervyn Peake and @@1866 -- now that's next level. (Clip should start around 2:25)

The physical prize given to the winner of the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction is a painting by Portland artist Julia Stoops. "Gathering for the Festival" is part of her Lissajous series. See the rest of the series here: www.juliastoops.net/p467319164
"Where Do You Get Your Ideas From?" was written in 1987, and appears in the collection Dancing at the Edge of the World (published by Grove Press in 1989).
Here's the cover for a French edition of Tales from Earthsea, coming from Livre de Poche.

Le Guin started writing A Wizard of Earthsea at the beginning of September 1966. Charles, her husband, took over the kids as soon as he was done grading finals and she finished the first draft two days before Christmas.
Congratulations to @@554579, winner of the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction for Arboreality!

Fact: We wanted to call it "The Ursula K. Le Guin Realists of a Larger Reality Prize for Fiction" but that was just too much of a mouthful. But those words are the spirit behind the Prize. We celebrate the shortlist & announce the 2023 winner at 5:30 pm (PDT) today: www.crowdcast.io/c/leguinpriz...

Welcome back, Catwings! Ursula's chapter books about a litter of winged kittens are now available again—in paperback, hardcover, and a box set that includes all four books.

(Pard approves.)

www.simonandschuster.com/series/Catwi...
Here are some people talking about our love for the work of Ursula K. Le Guin @@1866: Arwen Curry, So Mayer (@@184080), and me.

In just over two days, we'll announce the recipient of the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction! Join us and host Alicia Vikander online at 5:30 pm (PDT) Wednesday evening: www.crowdcast.io/c/leguinpriz...
Happy birthday, Ursula!

Next week, the recipient of the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction will be announced in an online event hosted by Alicia Vikander, featuring readings from all nine shortlisted novels! Join us at 5:30 pm Pacific time on Wednesday, October 25th: www.crowdcast.io/c/leguinpriz...

The final episode of The Journey That Matters, a series of short videos about Ursula's life and work from director Arwen Curry, is now up on LitHub. "He's My First Reader" looks at Ursula's relationship with her husband, Charles. Introduction by @@312769

lithub.com/watch-ursula...
.@@184080, look what I found: the first publication of @@1866's essay "The Space Crone," illustrated with photos of Ursula and her mother, Theodora Kroeber. CoEvolution Quarterly, June 1976.

Undated drawing by Ursula (ca. 1980s?).

Caption verso: Amiticia.

Ten Planets is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. Yuri Herrera's sly stories, elegantly translated by Lisa Dillman, are surreal yet familiar, offering new angles on humanity and connection. 

Register for the prize announcement event here: www.crowdcast.io/c/leguinpriz...

The fifth episode of The Journey That Matters, a series of short films about Ursula made by documentarian Arwen Curry, is now up at Lit Hub. Theo Downes-Le Guin introduces "Where I Write," a look at Ursula's study and her process. Watch here: lithub.com/watch-ursula...
The fifth book of Earthsea, Tales from Earthsea, is now available from The Folio Society. Like the rest of Folio's beautiful editions, it's illustrated by David Lupton.
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced in an online event on October 25th. Register here: www.crowdcast.io/c/leguinpriz...

Drinking from Graveyard Wells is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. Complex histories inform Yvette Lisa Ndlovu's stories, which meld folklore, myth, realism, and SFF elements into a cohesive whole.
Read about the shortlist here: electricliterature.com/announcing-t...
(Alicia Vikander photo by Gage Skidmore; used under Creative Commons Attribution Share-alike 2.0 Generic.)

Please join us on October 25th for an online event announcing the recipient of the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction! We'll welcome host Alicia Vikander and the nine shortlisted authors for an evening of readings and celebration.

Register here: www.crowdcast.io/c/leguinpriz...

Introducing the fourth of Arwen Curry's short films about Ursula, Khadija Abdalla Bajaber writes, "I have Le Guin to thank for opening my mind to science fiction. It’s not hard to open your mind to her. Often, it’s impossible not to." Watch here: lithub.com/watch-ursula...
You can find "The Good Trip" in The Wind's Twelve Quarters.
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced on October 25th. To read more about the prize or sign up for updates: www.ursulakleguin.com/prize23

Geometries of Belonging is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. Whether told in letters, stories, or narrative verse, R.B. Lemberg's tales from different corners of the Birdverse explore power, gender, art, and acceptance.

“I knew what Ged had to do. But I didn’t know where he was going to go and how he was going to do it.” 

Le Guin on her writing method in A Wizard of Earthsea (revealing herself as the pantser she was), plus a lovely short essay by John Plotz.
A note Ursula wrote to Todd Barton (Tabit, in Kesh) while they were working on the music and recordings for Always Coming Home.
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced in an online event on October 25th. To read more about the prize or sign up for notification emails: www.ursulakleguin.com/prize23

Wolfish is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. Christiane M. Andrews' novel for young readers is a story deeply interested in place, in the way nature can be an agent of change, and in how people can connect with each other and animals—or fail to.

"'Writing is communication,’ added the petite 43-year-old woman with sparkling eyes and a pixie haircut as she sat smoking a pipe in her 1899 four-story home in Northwest Portland.” 

From an 1973 interview with @@1866 in the Portland Oregonian, one of my favorite sentences ever.

The Journey That Matters, a series of short films by Arwen Curry, continues with “Elves, Dragons, and Countries That Didn’t Exist,” in which Ursula reflects on how her childhood influenced her development as a writer. With an introduction by @@64509, author of The Dark Fantastic.
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced in an online event on October 25th. To read more about the prize or sign up for notification emails: www.ursulakleguin.com/prize23

Arboreality is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. In looping, linked stories that travel through generations, Rebecca Campbell explores the regional, interpersonal, and cultural effects of climate change on one slice of British Columbia.

The Journey That Matters is a series of short videos from Arwen Curry, director of Worlds of Ursula K. Le Guin. The series begins with "What It Was Like," in which Ursula reads her 2004 piece about the abortion she had while studying at Radcliffe. Watch here: lithub.com/watch-ursula...

"Subversion Through Friendliness" was the motto of the Amalgamated Everlasting Union Chorus. Ursula had a print of the phrase in her office, and she embroidered this colorful version for Moe Bowstern, who shared the image & wrote about the motto at Substack: moebowstern.substack.com/p/happy-birt...

Simon Jimenez's structurally inventive second novel, The Spear Cuts Through Water, is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. The story of a kingdom being destroyed and—hopefully—rebuilt in a less cruel and violent form, it's a tale told in many voices, epic & intimate in scope
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced in an online event on October 25th. To read more about the prize or sign up for notification emails: www.ursulakleguin.com/prize23

Meet Us by the Roaring Sea is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. In Akil Kumarasamy's reflective story about survival, memory, & self, a young woman in near-future Queens translates a manuscript about a group of medical students facing drought and violence.
An undated, un-captioned drawing by Ursula.
Coming in November: Livre de Poche's two-volume French edition of The Hainish Novels and Stories: Le Livre de Hain Intégrale
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced in an online event on October 25th. To read more about the prize or sign up for notification emails: www.ursulakleguin.com/prize23

Brother Alive is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. Three adopted brothers reckon with the past of their parents and the man who adopted them in Zain Khalid's debut novel, which stretches across decades in a sharp critique of patriarchy, blind faith, capitalism, and more.
If you might be interested in a stack of Library of America editions of Ursula's work, you might want to make your way over to Instagram for a moment (US readers only, sorry!).
The recipient of this year's prize will be announced in an online event on October 25th. To read more about the prize or sign up for notification emails: https://www.ursulakleguin.com/prize23

Spear by @@55532 is shortlisted for the 2023 Ursula K. Le Guin Prize for Fiction. Griffith's fresh, queer rewriting of the Percival myth is the story of a young woman whose skills take her to the court of Artos—where she finds herself, and an unexpected home.

"For Le Guin, writing was a 'willingness to relinquish control, an act of trust.' Her universes were born of the belief that her imaginative instincts would take her where she needed to go — out among her fellow aliens and the stars."
Another new look for Lavinia: this Polish edition is coming from Prószyński i S-ka.

In early August of 1951, Ursula and her brother Karl were on their "Grand Tour" of Europe, traveling through Venice, Switzerland, Germany, and more. 

Atop Mt. Rigi, they were for one night the only guests in a striking old hotel.
Who gets to decide?

The cover for a new Italian edition of Lavinia, coming November 7th from Mondadori Libri. 

Design by Micaela Alcaino.
From Ursula to her mother, 1 August 1963. Those are Ursula's two daughters (third child not born yet). Happy August!
